fields.descriptive_line: Wheelbarrow with grooved wheel made for the tightrope walker Blondin (Jean Francçois Gravelet 1824-1897) to wheel passengers on a high wire, and may have been used for one of his 1859 crossings of Niagara Falls.
fields.physical_description: Wooden wheelbarrow with grooved metal wheel and red faded velvet lining.  The sides of the wheelbarrow were originally painted with decorative curved lines, but the paintwork is now faded.
fields.materials_techniques: Carved and painted wood with cast metal wheel
fields.public_access_description:
The great French tightrope walker Blondin (born Jean François Gravelet in 1824) first crossed Niagara Falls on a tightrope in twenty minutes, in June1859.  He made eight more crossings that summer, adding difficulties including crossing blindfold, at night, on stilts, on a bicycle, with his feet tied up in baskets, carrying people on his back, or in a wheelbarrow like this, especially made with a grooved wheel to stay on the rope.  In 1860 he performed several more crossings at Niagara, including one before the Prince of Wales who declined his offer of carrying him across the Falls. Blondin died in London in 1879 at his house in Ealing which he renamed Niagara.

A sale of Blondin's effects in London after his death in 1897 included two wheelbarrows and two bicycles used for his high wire crossings.  One of each is now in the Niagara Falls Museum, having been given by the son of an antique shop owner who discovered them in his cellar in 1959.  This wheelbarrow came from another London sale in 1923, so it is evident that Blondin had several made as essential properties for his act.
fields.bibliography: Daily Telegraph 25 August 1959 'BLONDIN RELICS' Report on two Blondin bicycles and wheelbarrows purchased by a Mr. Miller from a sale of Blondin's effects in 1897 which were discovered in 1959 in the cellar of his antique shop in Stepney. His son was considering offering them to F.J.G. Blondin, who was considering offering them to the Niagara Falls Museum. http://www.nfpl.library.on.ca/nfplindex/results.asp?sk=browse&q=295&key=294&start=61&db=5 Images of one of Blondin's wheelbarrows and bicycles.
fields.credit: Given by The Wellcome Institute for the History of Medicine
fields.history_note: This wheelbarrow was sold at Stevens's Auction Rooms, 38, King Street, Covent Garden, on Tuesday 21st August 1923, as lot 78 in a sale of' 'Arms and Armour and Ethnographical Specimens and Native Curios'. The lot was catalogued as 'The wheelbarrow, wire and trapese (sic) used by Blondin to cross the Niagara Falls; also photograph, 3 pictures, and 2 very strong trunks'. It was purchased by The Wellcome Institute for the History of Medicine who transferred it to the Bethnal Green Museum of Childhood in about 1982 believing it to be a child's toy, the original label having been lost. In 1985 its identification was discovered by Georgina Russell of the Wellcome Institute, and the object was transferred from the Museum of Childhood to the Theatre Collections. Two of Blondin's bicyles, and two similar wheelbarrows, were bought by a Mr. Miller in a sale of Blondin's effects in 1897, the year of his death. In 1959 they were found in the cellar of Mr. Miller's antique shop by his son Jack who offered them to Mr. F.J.G. Blondin who lived in Ealing. According to a report in The Daily Telegraph, 25 August 1959, he was considering offering one to Niagara Museum which contained 'relics of people who had performed feats at the Falls'. One wheelbarrow and one bicycle can be seen on the website of the Niagara Falls Public Library and is in the Kiwanis Collection of the Heritage Foundation Collection at Niagara (http://www.nfpl.library.on.ca/nfplindex/results.asp?sk=browse&q=295&key=294&start=61&db=5).
